utterances: To me, it wasn't an attack on the Somalian population or the Burmese population.
This was an attack on our community.
Finney County Sheriff Kevin Bascue agrees.
And Bascue says there's a third problem vexing immigration here.
Another Trump administration executive order could force local law enforcement to check the immigration status of otherwise law-abiding citizens.
Well, I think that the threat to this community is the ending of what we've worked so hard over many, many years to happen here.
The relationship between the police and the town's valued immigrant population.
I think our community would be a dying community without the immigrants that have come in to fill in the gaps and to grow business.
Bascue says law enforcement here will continue to cooperate fully with federal immigration agents but with an eye toward preserving Garden City's winning formula, which starts with immigrants.
For NPR News, I'm Frank Morris.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
You've probably heard the term ""Obamacons."" These are Republicans who voted for Barack Obama in the primaries.
Now, they are Obamacons, that is, conservatives for Obama, specifically neo-cons.
Bruce Bartlett writes about them in the current New Republic.
And Bruce Bartlett, who are these Obamacons?
Well, I think they're mostly conservatives who are just disgusted with the Iraq war, don't like George W.
Bush, view McCain as Bush's third term, and some others who just plain don't like John McCain anyway, because they don't really view him as being all that much of a conservative.
And I think that there are others who are attracted by Obama's oratory, his temperament, and generally hold out hope that he will be a good president.
And any names that we might be familiar with?
I would mention especially Jeffrey Hart, who is an editor of National Review, Wick Allison, former publisher of National Review Magazine.
Now the National Review, for people who aren't that familiar with it, that's considered the sort of intellectual brains of the conservative movement.
That's right.
That's the magazine that was founded by William F.
Buckley that has been long the anchor of the conservative movement.
So for somebody who has been associated with that magazine in a formal capacity to say publicly and on the record that they are supporting Barack Obama, I think, is quite significant.
Well, I can see why conservatives aren't happy with John McCain.
As you say, they don't trust him as a true conservative, but why would that necessarily mean that they would be for Barack Obama who is, by most characterizations, hardly conservative?
I think it's just the feeling that you've got to throw the bums out, is a lot of it.

I should say there's a widespread view in conservative circles that the only way of rebuilding the Republican Party and the conservative movement and purging it of Bushian and Rovian heresies is to just defeat these guys as badly as possible and rebuild on a new foundation.
What are the main issues that these conservatives take issue with, with President Bush, and then, by extension, John McCain?
There's a lot of dis - even hatred, dislike, of the Iraq war.
It's widely believed that every conservative supports the war down the line, but that's not true.
There's always been, from the very beginning, a small but vocal percentage of conservatives who thought it was just a disaster, and who have become, you know, more emboldened as time has gone by.
Also, there is a feeling that the budget has just gotten completely out of control under this administration.
And I think that there's also some specific issues where conservatives who had problems with John McCain for many years, most particularly campaign-finance reform.
And I think there's a feeling that McCain is always ready to sell conservatives out in a moment to get a good editorial about him in the New York Times.
OK, so these prominent conservatives have come out in support of Barack Obama.
Will they actually be active in their support?
Will they campaign for him?
Will they write editorials for him?
I cannot think of another explanation that makes all of our data tell a cohesive story other than it's emanating from the spill.
Her team is mapping what they think is a massive plume of polluted water that stretches more than 12 miles from the well to the west and southwest.
It's two miles across and a couple thousand feet tall.
The closer to the well the samples were taken, the more highly concentrated the oil and gas are.
Other independent scientists have found different big plumes, and federal scientists are on the hunt now, too.
But so far, federal officials and BP say they cannot confirm that Deepwater Horizon is creating big underwater plumes.
Joye believes she'll have the proof soon.
We're going to fingerprint this petroleum that we're finding in these plumes.
The scientists say they've seen a lot of dead jellyfish, but they know Deepwater Horizon's toll is much greater than what they can see.
Oil is toxic at 10 parts per million, and even BP's data shows concentrations at that level.
But everyone agrees almost nothing is known about the effect all that oil is having far underwater.
What is the impact?
We don't know.
Frank Muller-Karger is an oceanographer at the University of South Florida.
How large is the impact?
We don't know.
Where exactly is it happening below the surface?
We don't know.
So all of these things are frustrating.
Muller-Karger says what he does know is it's springtime, when the deep waters of the Gulf are full of fish eggs.
After a couple of days, an egg turns into something called a larva.
And it starts feeding on whatever it sees, and it expects to see food, not little oil droplets.
And it will eat oil droplets, because they just open their mouth and eat whatever they see.
So this is what's happening, and it's happening to sensitive species like the bluefin tuna.
Scientists say it should not have surprised BP and the government that so much of the oil stayed submerged.
Government studies had predicted it would do this.
Prosanta Chakrabarty from Louisiana State University is especially worried about a community of bizarre-looking ancient fish that live in the deep depths of the Gulf.
One of them, a pancake batfish, is a new species that he helped discover.
And now their once very stable habitat is covered in oil.
These fish hide out near the bottom, but there's very little food for them there.
What happens is, at night, they use the cover of darkness to kind of come up closer to the surface to eat.
That's means they're swimming a mile or more, sometimes every day.
We don't know if they can avoid plumes that are miles long and hundreds of feet deep.
And Chakrabarty says while there are lots of plans to clean up the oil on the surface, no one has any strategy for cleaning up the deep water.
Elizabeth Shogren, NPR News.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
Good morning.
It is April 14th, and procrastinators know this.
It means you've still got a full day before you need to start doing your taxes.
This year, the federal deficit has fueled debate over how much we should be paying the government, and so has the conservative Tea Party movement - Tea, of course, standing for taxed enough already.
In a moment, we'll hear about the real Tea Party.
We'll start with another part of the debate.
Some wealthy people are lobbying Congress with the message: tax me more.
NPR's Yuki Noguchi reports.
Marnie Thompson is, in a way, still trying to make amends for growing up rich.
I knew we were wealthier than most folks because my folks weren't into flaunting it, but they also sent us to private schools.
I went to dancing school.
To make my mother happy, I was even a debutante.
But Thompson did not want to carry on money traditions, so she gave what would've been her inheritance, $5 million, to charity.
Now Thompson doesn't own a cell phone, but she feels she and her husband still have too much.
You want your taxes to be raised, currently.
Yeah.
Absolutely.
And Thompson will likely get her wish.
The Bush administration put in place a series of tax cuts that will sunset at the end of the year.
That means income taxes will likely increase for those making more than $250,000, though Congress is expected to extend the cuts for households making less than that.
The capital gains taxes will also return to their pre-Bush levels.
But it's less clear how much of the dividend taxes Congress will reinstate, or how estate taxes will be phased back in.
